Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of my laptop blending with the distant clatter of dishes from the kitchen. My mother’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me of the family gathering tonight—an event steeped in tradition, where my presence was not just expected, but required. Lately, my family had become more insistent about honoring our customs, especially as the older generation grew more nostalgic. 

But my phone buzzed with another email from my project manager, the subject line urgent: “Prototype update needed by tomorrow.” The stakeholders were growing impatient, and the success of our project—and my reputation as an engineer—hinged on delivering a working model. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me, the pull of family loyalty clashing with the demands of my career. My heart raced as I glanced between the family group chat and the technical schematics, torn by the fear of disappointing those I love or letting down my team.
